As Congress works to formulate the reauthorization of the FAA this year, and until we ensure the safety of the flight deck from physical intrusion, I will not stop pushing for the extension of this requirement for secondary cockpit barriers to all passenger airplanes.

I am proud to continue to champion the bipartisan Saracini Enhanced Aviation Safety Act (HR 911), named for my constituent Captain Victor Saracini who lost his life on 9/11 when the cockpit of his airplane, Flight 175, was breached and flown into the South Tower.

Yesterday, the @USDOT issued a final rule to require secondary cockpit barriers on covered passenger aircraft from the moment of manufacture. While this action is a step in the right direction, the fight is far from being over.

Last July, I asked @SecretaryPete during a @TransportGOP hearing about the inconsistent application and delayed implementation of that rule. One week later, the FAA finally announced a proposed rule and began accepting public comment.

In 2018, I led a bipartisan group in pushing for the inclusion of the Saracini Aviation Safety Act in the FAA Reauthorization Act. That provision required the FAA to issue a rule within 1 year mandating secondary barriers on all new aircraft coming off production lines.

üßµSince I came to Congress, I have fought to make our skies and aircraft more secure for our pilots, flight crews, passengers, and their families to make sure that a tragedy like 9/11 never happens again.

Howard Middleton was an icon, an early pioneer in integrating this city, and a man whose giant shoes will be hard to fill‚Äîhis legacy will never end. My deepest sympathy to his wife Doris and the entire Middleton family.

It wasn't heard of when he began to approach the first livestock show, but Howard was committed; his legacy has generated thousands and thousands of dollars in scholarships for young people in our community.
I enjoyed personally working with Howard and personally working with him in the early founding of the 'Go Black Texan Committee‚Äô.
He was a founding father of the 'Go Black Texan Committee,' one of the largest programs of the Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo now called the 'Black Heritage Committee‚Äô.
He lived civil rights and labor rights, and he knew business very well. He was a leader in the local NAACP and one of the first African Americans appointed to the sports authority.

Our friend Howard Middleton has passed. Howard was an early leader in the labor movement, a family man, a husband, a father, and a grandfather. He was a man who never had any doubt that if he fought for something, he would get it done.
